chapter.title: Virtual Machines
chapter.para:
The VM specific elements which may be contained in the virtual machine description are as follows:
type One of DESKTOP or SERVER
status One of PAUSED, RUNNING, SHUTDOWN or SHUTOFF
memory The amount of memory allocated to the guest, in bytes
cpu The CPU topology (i.e. number of sockets and cores available to the guest)
os A list of boot devices (using boot dev) - either cdrom, hd or network
host A reference to the host which this VM is currently running on. See
cluster A reference to the cluster on which this VM will run. See
template A reference to the template on which this VM is based. See
vmpool A reference to the VM pool which this VM is a member of. See
devices A collection of cdrom, disk or nic elements
For example:

chapter.para: When creating a new VM, the name, template and cluster elements are required. The template and cluster may be identified by id or name. The name, description, type, memory, cpu topology and os boot dev properties may be updated post-creation.
There are five possible actions for hosts - start, stop, shutdown, suspend, detach and migrate.

section.title: Devices
section.para: A VM's devices are represented and managed through a number of collections which behave similarly to other collections, as described by .
There are three device collections available for each VM - cdroms, disks and nics. The URI for each of these collections are available via link elements in the VM representation.

section.title: CD-ROM Devices
section.para:
CD-ROM devices are represented by a cdrom element containing the following properties:
iso id A reference to an ISO image. See
When adding a new CD-ROM, the iso id property is required.

note.para: Note that a VM may currently only have a single CD-ROM and it is not possible to modify the CD-ROM properties using PUT.

section.title: Disk Devices
section.para:
Disk devices are represented by a disk element containing the following properties:
size The size, in bytes, of the disk
type DATA, SHARED, SWAP, SYSTEM or TEMP
status ILLEGAL, INVALID, LOCKED or OK
interface IDE, SCSI or VIRTIO
format COW or RAW
sparse true if the physical storage for the disk should not be preallocated
bootable true if this disk is to be marked as bootable
wipe_after_delete true if the underlying physical storage for the disk should be zeroed when the disk is deleted
propagate_errors true if disk errors should not cause VM to be paused and, instead, disk errors should be propagated to the guest OS
When adding a new disk, the size property is required.

note.para: Note that it is not possible to modify disk properties using PUT.

section.title: Network Interface Devices
section.para:
Network interface devices are represented by a nic element containing the following properties:
name The name of the guest network device, e.g. eth0
network id A reference to the network which the interface should be connected
type E1000, PV, RTL8139 or RTL8139_PV
mac address The MAC address of the interface
ip address/netmask/gateway IP level details on the interface configuration, obtained from a guest agent if available
When adding a new network interface, the name and network id properties are required.

note.para: Note that it is not possible to modify network interface properties using PUT.

section.title: Snapshots
section.para: A VM may have any number of snapshots of its disk state and these are represented and managed through a collection which behaves similarly to other collections, as described by .

VM snapshots are represented by a snapshot element containing the following snapshot-specific properties:
vm The ID and URI of the VM to which this snapshot pertains
date The date and time which this snapshot was created (using the xsd:dateTime format, i.e. YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss)
link rel="prev" A link to the previous snapshot of this VM
When adding a new disk, only the description property may be specified.

note.para: Note that it is not possible to modify snapshot properties using PUT.

section.title: Shutdown Action
section.para: Request that a VM shuts down.

section.title: Suspend Action
section.para: Save the VM state to disk and stop it. The VM state can later be restored using the start action.

section.title: Detach Action
section.para: Detach a VM from a VM pool.

section.title: Migrate Action
section.para: Migrate a VM to another physical host. The destination host id or name is a required parameter.
